description.en: This course focuses on the conceptualisation and application of cultural heritage in diverse geographic, socio-cultural and economic contexts, paying particular attention to the sphere of intangible cultural heritage. The roles of cultural heritage in local, national and international cultural policy and economics are discussed with regard to different needs and resources in different parts of the world. The use of past practices, artefacts, expressions and forms of communication are discussed in a contemporary context where, under the conditions of tourism, branding and migration, cultural heritage serves as a socio-cultural and economic resource. The analysis of heritage policy distinguishes between symbolic, social and material interests.
description.et: Kursus keskendub kultuuripärandi mõtestamisele ja rakendamisele erinevas geograafilises, ühiskondlik-kultuurilises ja majanduslikus kontekstis, pöörates ainelise kõrval süvendatumat tähelepanu vaimse kultuuripärandi sfäärile. Analüüsitakse kultuuripärandi rolli kohalikus, riiklikus ja rahvusvahelises kultuuripoliitikas ning majanduses, lähtudes erinevatest vajadustest ja võimalustest maailma eri piirkondades. Vaadeldakse minevikupraktikate, artefaktide, väljenduste ja suhtlusvormide kasutust tänases kontekstis, kus kaasaegse turisminduse, brändingu ja migratsiooni tingimustes toimib kultuuripärand ühiskondlik-kultuurilise ning majandusliku ressursina. Pärandipoliitika kujundamist analüüsides eritletakse sümboolse, sotsiaalse ja materiaalse huvi tasandit.

objectives.et: Anda sissevaade uuringutesse, mis käsitlevad kultuuripärandi temaatikat laias ühiskondlik-kultuurilises ja majanduslikus kontekstis. Õpetada kultuuripoliitika ja kultuuriprotsesside analüütilist uurimisviisi ning tutvustada kaasaegseid meetodeid antud väljal. Eritleda kultuuripärandiga seotud potentsiaali või probleeme.

learning_outcomes.et: Aine läbinud üliõpilane 1) tunneb kultuuripärandi uuringute põhilisi teooriaid ja mõisteid ning oskab neid omavahel suhestada; 2) omab ülevaadet kultuuripärandi poliitiliste, majanduslike ja ühiskondlike rakendustega seotud võimalustest ja probleemidest; 3) oskab seostada kaasaegseid kultuuriprotsesse kultuuripoliitiliste toimemehhanismidega; 4) oskab rakendada omandatud teadmisi nii individuaalses uurimistöös kui ka rühmatöös.

description.en: This class will introduce the course content and schedule, the rationale of instruction methods, and assignments. Students will get to know each other and will reflect on their previous relations with heritage. Discussion of the concepts of "heritage" and "heritagisation" will serve as a starting point for further exploration of the course themes.

topic.en: 2. Politics and policy of culture and heritage

description.en: This class will examine the interplay between politics and cultural heritage, exploring how policy decisions reflect broader political agendas and shape cultural and heritage frameworks (on paper and on the ground).

topic.en: 3. Politics of culture and preservation agenda

description.en: This class will trace back the evolution of the concept of heritage and ideas related to its preservation, exploring the factors that triggered and influenced those developments globally and locally. The way they "translated" into relevant policies will be studied in relation to UNESCO's standard-setting instruments concerning cultural heritage (conventions, recommendations, declarations).

This class will look at UNESCO as the leading international organisation in the heritage field. Its operational principles will be explored together with its contribution to the formation of the heritage agenda by means of international treaties (1972 Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage and 2003 Convention for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage).

topic.en: 5. UNESCO, cultural politics, and intangible cultural heritage (ICH)

description.en: This class will focus on intangible cultural heritage and safeguarding approaches established within the UNESCO ICH framework, with listing being one of them. The class will feature a guest speaker: Prof. Kristin Kuutma, who has served in different capacities outside academia on the international and local levels.

topic.en: 6. Heritage in Estonia (field trip to Tallinn)

description.en: The field trip will provide insights into the implementation of heritage policies and heritage management on the national level. It will include a meeting with invited guest speakers active in the heritage field (TBC). In addition, it will feature a guided tour of the Tallinn old town and a visit to the Ukrainian Culture Centre.

Start of work on the group assignment, management plan for an ICH element of your choice. Choosing an element, background research, preparing for a short (max 3 minutes) pitch presentation on 09.04.2025.

topic.en: 7. ICH policy implications on the ground

description.en: This class will provide further insights into the implementation of heritage policies and heritage management on the national and local levels. It will feature two guest speakers: Epp Tamm, an ICH specialist of the Estonian Centre of Folk Culture, and a representative of a local heritage initiative (TBC).

This class will look at the issues of ICH management in various regional contexts. Following the pitch presentation of management plan ideas, group work will continue to identify safeguarding challenges of the ICH elements in question and develop a set of safeguarding measures to address them.
This class will examine the complex issues of ownership in relation to intangible cultural heritage, exploring legal and ethical frameworks that engage with community rights and agency.

This class will explore the interconnections between heritage and sustainability frameworks with particular attention to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. It will look closer at whether heritage can serve as a resource for sustainable development and whether sustainable development principles can enhance heritage safeguarding.

This class will address connections between heritage and cultural diversity, exploring the role of cultural and creative industries within the heritage frameworks.

The course will conclude with a recap of relevant concepts and policy developments in the heritage sphere and their application on the international, national and local levels. In addition, students will be encouraged to reflect on the possible role(s) of academically trained professionals in the heritage field.
